This heavy armored suit, known as the TB-1, possesses a high physical protection comparing to the original Radiation suits. For all other parameters it’s identical to exoskeleton, except for a slightly less ballistic and rupture protection. Composed of three elements; a tactical helmet, a heavy armoured vest and reinforced jumpsuit. This set is used by master Stalkers traveling through dead forests of the north, who have to be ready not only for fights with mutants, but also increased number of chemical and electrical anomalies in addition to higher radiation levels. It bears a bleak woodland camouflage, with slight, greyish spots and stripes. \n \n
Bandits radiation suit (TB-1 Digital Earth Camo)

This heavy armored suit, known as the TB-1, possesses a high physical protection comparing to the original Radiation suits. For all other parameters it’s identical to exoskeleton, except for a slightly less ballistic and rupture protection. Composed of three elements; a tactical helmet, a heavy armoured vest and reinforced jumpsuit. This set bears a digital camouflage pattern of brown, grey and black pixels. It has been additionally hardened and uses plates made of tougher but heavier kinds of steel; additional thermo-resistant layer prevents the wearer from both incendiary and thermite grenades, as well as from thermal anomalies. On the other hand, the outfit is more vulnerable to acids and its metal reinforcements conduct electricity; it is also almost a kilogram heavier than the regular TB-1.\n \n

This heavy armored suit, known as the TB-1, possesses a high physical protection comparing to the original Radiation suits. For all other parameters it’s identical to exoskeleton, except for a slightly less ballistic and rupture protection. Composed of three elements; a tactical helmet, a heavy armoured vest and reinforced jumpsuit. This set is made of lighter but less physically resistant components, which on the other hand are less susceptible to acids and are worse electricity conductors. The suit can also be slightly adjusted to better fit the wearer's body, decreasing the discomfort and allowing for more "agile" movement. The breathing apparatus of the integrated helmet was also reworked to not only filter the air more efficiently, but also makes breathing slightly easier. Nickname "Vineleaf" comes from the suit's camouflage pattern, resembling the leaves of poisonous ivy.\n \n

This heavy armored suit, known as the TB-1, possesses a high physical protection comparing to the original Radiation suits. For all other parameters it’s identical to exoskeleton, except for a slightly less ballistic and rupture protection. Composed of three elements; a tactical helmet, a heavy armoured vest and reinforced jumpsuit. Even though it lacks anomalous protection (when compared to the original) it boasts even higher defences agains heavy impacts, blunt strikes, cuts and mutant attacks. It also possesses increased psy protection thanks to lead-reinforced helmet. Even though this lead layer is relatively thin, it is enough to almost double the protection without making the hemlet overly heavy. The suit bears standard Duty colors - grey with black and red accents.\n \n

This heavy armored suit, known as the TB-1, possesses a high physical protection comparing to the original Radiation suits. For all other parameters it’s identical to exoskeleton, except for a slightly less ballistic and rupture protection. Composed of three elements; a tactical helmet, a heavy armoured vest and reinforced jumpsuit. This variant of Duty TB-1 is designed for units hunting down especially dangerous mutants. Its physical defences and psy protection were increased, at the cost of lower anomalous protection. It bears the popular Krasnyy-style color pattern - mainly black, with dark red accents with a slight metallic gloss.\n \n

This heavy armored suit, known as the TB-1, possesses a high physical protection comparing to the original Radiation suits. For all other parameters it’s identical to exoskeleton, except for a slightly less ballistic and rupture protection. Composed of three elements; a tactical helmet, a heavy armoured vest and reinforced jumpsuit. This variant of Duty TB-1 is used mainly by squads sent for conducting mutant population control operations in the Red Forest and surrounding areas. Due to high anomalous activity in the area, the suit has been reinforced to gain higher protection from elements at the cost of lowered shrapnel, impact and gunfire defences. It also possesses a dark woodland camouflage pattern; red accents, iconic for Duty, were made less glossy and painted to give them a greyish tint.\n \n

This heavy armored suit, known as the TB-1, possesses a high physical protection comparing to the original Radiation suits. For all other parameters it’s identical to exoskeleton, except for a slightly less ballistic and rupture protection. Composed of three elements; a tactical helmet, a heavy armoured vest and reinforced jumpsuit. This variant of Duty TB-1 is most suited for urban combat. It has been additionally armored, providing better protection from shrapnels and bullets; thicker armor also slightly decreases external psy influence on the wearer. Increased physical defences lead to decreased thermal and electrical protection - armored also erode easily when exposed to strong acids or chemical fumes. The suit bears standard Duty urban camouflage, with its iconic red accents still present.\n \n

This heavy armored suit, known as the TB-1, possesses a high physical protection comparing to the original Radiation suits. For all other parameters it’s identical to exoskeleton, except for a slightly less ballistic and rupture protection. Composed of three elements; a tactical helmet, a heavy armoured vest and reinforced jumpsuit. Used by expert Mercenaries on missions in the north, for taking down elite squads of the Monolith. It bears a standard merc dark blue camouflage pattern, suitable for operations in urban environment (or anywhere else, but only at nighttime). \n \n

This heavy armored suit, known as the TB-1, possesses a high physical protection comparing to the original Radiation suits. For all other parameters it’s identical to exoskeleton, except for a slightly less ballistic and rupture protection. Composed of three elements; a tactical helmet, a heavy armoured vest and reinforced jumpsuit. It also bears a camouflage pattern almost identical to that used on Mercenary fighter suits and the combat SEVA suit. \n \n

This heavy armored suit, known as the TB-1, possesses a high physical protection comparing to the original Radiation suits. For all other parameters it’s identical to exoskeleton, except for a slightly less ballistic and rupture protection. Composed of three elements; a tactical helmet, a heavy armoured vest and reinforced jumpsuit. This version is used for Mercenaries pursuing Monolith squads around the forests of Zaton and other northern forested areas. Aside from the camouflage pattern, it also possesses increased protection agains anomalous threats and radiation. \n \n

This heavy armored suit, known as the TB-1, possesses a high physical protection comparing to the original Radiation suits. For all other parameters it’s identical to exoskeleton, except for a slightly less ballistic and rupture protection. Composed of three elements; a tactical helmet, a heavy armoured vest and reinforced jumpsuit. This variant of Mercenary TB-1, meant for use by Mercs sent to complete tasks in areas with little cover, where to stay hidden you need to lower your profile and hide in the tall grass. Even though it may seem funny, considering the suit's protection (in this case also increased against mutant threat) it is always better to surprise the enemy than to get shot at immidiately - especially if you work by yourself, as most of this suit's users do. The set is also made of slightly lighter materials, making wearing it just a bit less tiring.\n \n

This heavy armored suit, known as the TB-1, possesses a high physical protection comparing to the original Radiation suits. For all other parameters it’s identical to exoskeleton, except for a slightly less ballistic and rupture protection. Composed of three elements; a tactical helmet, a heavy armoured vest and reinforced jumpsuit.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]A stalker bodysuit, fitted with parts from an exoskeleton for additional protection against ballistics. Despite the fact that the rest of the armour is often strained by anything beyond even pistol bullets, the suit enjoys great popularity due to its low cost and modification potential.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]A lightweight stalker bodysuit, made by Freedom craftsmen and fitted with parts from an exoskeleton for additional protection. The suit’s fabric is treated with Horizon, a special solution developed by the faction by trial and error, to increase resistance to anomalies.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]This modern version of the Duty bodysuit has been fitted with parts from an exoskeleton for additional protection. Unlike the PSZ series, the rest of the suit provides reasonable protection against anomalies while also being capable of stopping a pistol bullet.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]This early model of the Duty bodysuit is the Spetsnaz PSZ-9 body armour modified for the Zone. The suit is capable of stopping a rifle bullet, however, this level of protection comes at the cost of its weight, bulkiness and virtually non-existent anomaly protection. Mounted exoskeleton provdes extra carry weight.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]This modern military armoured suit is designed for assault operations in anomalous areas. Comprises a PSZ-12p heavy military armoured suit, built-in compensation suit, an anomalous protection bodysuit, mounted exoskeleton. The armour provides excellent protection against bullet and fragmentation damage, without reducing the wearer’s mobility.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]An armour made by either Monolithians or an unknown manufacturer. It includes a flak vest of unknown origin and also features unique modifications creating a slight resistance to radiation. System has mounted exoskeleton.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]A Clear Sky branded sunrise bodysuit. Despite the fact that the body armour is incapable of protecting the wearer from even pistol bullets, the suit enjoys great popularity within Clear Sky members due to its low cost and modification potential. Integrated with an exoskeleton.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]An Ecologist armoured bodysuit, designed for assault and support operations in anomalous areas. Despite the fact that the body armour cannot provide the necessery protection the exo-skeleton offers, the suit has optimized combat performance. The exo-frames are capable of providing mechanical support for carrying heavy loads along with built-in isolating artefact containers, making it a great choice to aid researchers during science trips inside the Zone.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]Outfit of choice for the UNISG forces, fitted with parts from an exoskeleton for additional protection against ballistics. Very similar in its design to STS bodysuits. Designed to sustain durability under various conditions inside the Zone. Due to a special treatment of the fabric, the armour has a strengthened stability during the physical movement of its plates. Comes with built-in body armour and armour attachment modules.

%c[ui_gray_1]An experimental sample of a military exoskeleton. Was never mass-produced due to extraordinary cost and some design flaws. Despite this, it is in demand due to its ability to take on the weight of all carried equipment, and therefore small batches are made in underground facilities outside Ukraine. Comes with a built-in artefact container.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]Excellent high-tech armour. Domestically developed by one of the research institutes, specifically for the Duty faction. Equipped with advanced battle features, such as enhanced servos and reinforced steel plates. Painted in Duty’s faction colours.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]Produced by Freedom’s finest artisans. Experimenting with different modifications, after numerous attempts they managed to create a really successful design. Painted in the colours of the Freedom faction. Comparable with Duty’s exoskeleton to some extent.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]An experimental sample of a military exoskeleton of western production for equipping mercenaries and other armed groups. Since the focus is on combat usability and resilience, it has low anomaly protection.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]High-tech armour, made on the basis of an army exoskeleton. The technologies applied to customise the exo are unknown. In the materials’ composition, from which some parts of the armour are made, were found previously unknown elements and alloys.\n \n
%c[ui_gray_1]Version of a military exoskeleton customised by bandits to attack well-guarded facilities and to plunder well-armed stalkers. Painted in dark colours to reduce visibility.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]The official version of a military exoskeleton. Released in limited quantities by special order of the military stalkers. Designed to counter well-armed and equipped hostile groups of individuals in the territory of the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]An experimental version of the army exoskeleton assembled in a controlled environment by Clear Sky engineers, offers good anomaly protection, with emphasis put on combat application. It also provides light psychic protection.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]This exoskeleton model is not designed to conduct active combat operations because of its high visibility. Released in limited edition, special order for scientists. Combat parameters are significantly reduced. There have been attempts to use it in scientific expeditions to protect scientists and to transfer heavy-duty scientific equipment. However, they failed miserably, as the person in such a noticeable suit became the number one target.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]One of several exoskeletons of the long-defeated group of the Renegades. Was found by Clear Sky soldiers in the hideouts of the faction in the swamps and, judging by the condition, never used in combat. By design, defensive and combat options, style and colour scheme it’s quite similar to its Bandit counterpart.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]The official version of a UNISG exoskeleton. Released in limited quantities by special order of the UNISG forces. Designed to counter well-armed and equipped hostile groups of individuals in the territory of the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]High-tech armour, made on the basis of an army exoskeleton. The technologies applied to customise the exo are unknown. In the materials’ composition, from which some parts of the armour are made, were found previously unknown elements and alloys.\n \n

The heaviest of all armored suits available in the Zone and outside it. Nosorog, also known as the Rhino, was designed for seemingly suicidal operations deep within the Zone. It is used by the most elite extermination squads for hunting down the most deadly mutants, like pseudogiants and chimeras, and for the most dangerous assault operations conducted in far north. In operations like those, it is used by point men carrying heavy weaponry, like the PKM or RG-6; its operators don't have to use any cover for most of the time, as they are able to literally tank any incoming gunfire. Nosorog is pretty much impervious to any physical damage sources other than highly explosive materials, and it's easier to kill the user with sheer force of explosions than to damage the suit itself. Its major weak point is the extremly high vulnerability to chamical fumes and acids, which can damage its mechanisms with ease. It is also made almost entirely out of metal parts, which greatly amplify electrical discharges; strong heat is another great threat - the wearer can be literally cooked inside the armor. Main components of the armor are doubly reinforced TB-1 suit, lead-reinforced mTR-33 "Spartan" ballistic helmet with mounted third generation night vision device, and an integrated exoskeleton.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]During the finest hour of Clear Sky, this bodysuit served as standard issue for the faction’s light assault troops. This suit is not only capable of stopping lesser bullets, but also provides a fair amount of protection against anomalous exposure.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]Once used as a standard by Clear Sky assault squads, after the faction’s elimination, this armour serves as a reminder that even an excellent protective bodysuit cannot guarantee safety on the wrong side of the perimeter. The armour is capable of stopping a pistol bullet, while the wearer is also reasonably protected from anomalies.\n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]PSZ-7p Pantsir is an armored suit developed shortly after Duty lost their influence in Yanov station. Forced to fall back and taking numerous casualties, the faction decided to start a research in order to develop an armored suit lighter and cheaper, but still almost as protective as their PSZ-9d suit. The fruit of this project was the Pantsir, which has become the standard issue outfit for Duty's assault squads. It consists of two parts. The main part is the outfit itself - trousers and jacket made from thick fabric and additionally padded, to decrease the froce of strong impacts and prevent the outfit from being torn or cut. The second part is its bulletproof vest, made of several separate armored plates forming a kind of a scale armor, which are able to easily stop lower caliber bullets and grenade shrapnels. The vest is covered with a layer of reinforced fabric, and fits the body surprisingly well, only slightly limiting the wearer's movement. Vest is attached and held together by straps made from a strong, sytnthetic fabric, additionally reinforced with outer layer of hardened leather. The suit can be upgraded in a wide variety of ways by attaching additional armor plates, pockets or containers - all of that thanks to its simple yet solid construction. The main weakness of this outfit is its vulnerability to acids; the fabric also easily burns, and metal components conduct electricity, posing additional threat to the wearer. Pantsir was designed for use with the mTR-33 "Spartan" ballistic helmet, which greatly fits and improves basic qualities of the suit. \n \n

%c[ui_gray_1]This suit is designed to simulate a ‘heap of foliage.’ Usually this type of suits are worn by snipers and hunters to blend in with the environment and hide themselves from enemies. Ghillie suits are commercially produced, but usually both military personnel and civilians customise and improve them to suit their needs. Despite its high efficiency, it can be very impractical: even in a temperate climate, it becomes hot over time and is very heavy.\n \n
